commentBody: My Friday best *and* I got tripped up in the northwest. Super breezy Friday, IMO.

Fine Friday fun. 
Thanks, gents.
Easy, breezy, beautiful. Enjoyed it a lot, would have liked it chewier though! Didnâ€™t even see all the clues today :/
I was very confident in my made-up word, POOPART.  Alas, it wasn't to be.

Very good cluing today, misleading but clever with that 'OOHHH' payoff you want.

I had a real tough time with OENOPHILIA cause I hadn't heard of the word, I kept thinking it was about Cincinnati Reds fans and the crossings were tricky.  While I have heard of Singapore Sling I hadn't heard of GINSLING so I kept triyng to make it SINSLING or GUNSLING.  Then I kept thinking PROP ART instead of PLOP ART.

Then in SW area for the Swiss army knife clue I kept thinking it was OMNITOOL or POLYTOOL which made it tough to get any of the crossings until LIFESTYLE CREEP finally clicked.

I'm with Sam on not knowing "rowdy" could be a noun, but M-W says it is true (second definition).

This was my 1800th completed puzzle.

I had a hard time getting started in this one. Probably because I tried cincymania and cincymafia for reds fandom. I groaned when the wine connection became clear, and then the puzzle fell into place.  Is PLOPART really a term that people use? I liked LIFESTYLECREEP, as an entry, not a mode of being.

Webster's answer to Sam's question about the noun "rowdy" is: since 1865 rowdy 2 of 2 noun plural rowdies : a rowdy person : tough First Known Use [as a noun] 1865, in the meaning defined above (https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rowdy)
Can anyone tell me what's in the picture?

Thanks everyone who supported me yesterday and ultimately convinced me to keep commenting. Iâ€™ll try to have a thicker skin, but I do hope we can not only be more thoughtful and respectful ourselves but speak up when we see inappropriate comments since the Times really canâ€™t moderate everythingâ€”and recognize that everyone may have different limits about what is tolerable. Enough said.
Anyways I could hardly stay away from a puzzle that references Reds fandom, even tangentially. I figured it had to do with wine but couldnâ€™t pull the term outâ€”in fact that corner almost stumped me until JICAMA crept out of the crevices of my brain.
I loved this. It started a lot harder than it ended up for me, but a lot of sparkling entries and clueing. I especially liked a lot of the creative clues for some short answers â€”OWL, BIB, APB, TAN. Loved PLOPART, will definitely add that to my active vocabulary. I can certainly confirm the difficulty of 14 letter entries, this was an elegant grid under the circumstances, surprised they didnâ€™t cave and just use a 14 x 16 (how do I know? Just submitted one myself, we will see if it flies).
My only regret for the puzzle is the lack of a cleverer clue for ITSASMALLWORLD. Not that itâ€™s a gimmeâ€”SPLASHMOUNTAIN has the same number of letters, ask me how I knowâ€”but get any piece of it and the rest is obvious, would have loved to have been stumped longer on such a fun entry.  But overall tremendously enjoyable, and Rafael Musa rarely fails to deliver.
Bantu knot mention for Black History Month!!

A slow start for me, but once I had a toehold the pace accelerated. My solve today was all over the place, and fill the missing parts in later, unlike my usual top to bottom progression on most puzzles. Also unusual is that I got most of the answers correct on the first try, even though the first and last entries for an answer could be a long time apart. Of course, there were a few that had to be revised to fit the crosses.

Nice Friday challenge for me, thanks, guys!
I really didn't think I would see a picture of an echidna blowing a snot bubble today but here we are.

I felt like I was moving slowly, especially in the SW. I then finished well below my Friday average. I thoroughly enjoyed the puzzle, both the clueing and the fill. 

LIFESTYLECREEP is terrific. Iâ€™ve been a car nut all my life and fondly remember my folks 1954 Ford wagon, lacking absolutely everything I take for granted in my 11 year old Subaru.
Pretty breezy for a Friday. Mostly enjoyed the fill, OENOPHILIA crossed with GINSLING was gross though

Itâ€™ll take weeks to get that ear-worm* out of my head, otherwise enjoyed this one very much.  

*not spelled out in case you dislike it as much as I do.
My LIFESTYLE CREEP acquisition:  a battery powered little whizzy doodad for frothing milk.  To think I spent all these years just putting plain milk in my coffee!

The kind of Friday that makes me feel good about myself. Not too easy. Enough but to make me nervous. But ultimately very smooth. 

The Redâ€™s clue had me thinking baseball the entire time.  Then USSR or China. An entry that starts with two vowels is dastardly.  

Never heard of lifestyle creep. But I like it. Like how I canâ€™t even google anything anymore.  I have to ask Claude.  Because I donâ€™t want to synthesize information.  At least I didnâ€™t ask â€˜himâ€™ to edit this comment.

Iâ€™m a big fan of Rafael Musa who seems like a happy person and whose puzzles always make me a happy solver. This first-time collaboration with Geoffrey Schorkopf was no exception. However, like Sam, I had never heard of 7Down and was ever so slightly disappointed that the L was not an O.

Great collaboration!  Enjoyable solve, as always, when Mr. Musa is involved. JICAMA was my favorite afternoon treat when I worked at a hospital in East LA. The street vendors served it with chile powder and lime juice, sometimes mixed with watermelon. Yum! If only I could have had a GINSLING to go with it.  Happy Friday!
Thanks for LIFESTYLECREEPâ€¦ now I know what thatâ€™s called!

LIFESTYLECREEP
It's hard to imagine paying the bus fare with an "OMNY" card. But can you all imagine that the bus driver actually used to make change for a dollar? He had this little silver machine with all the coins lined up. Of course, nowadays, you can never go anywhere without it being "a matter of public record!"

Also, back then, people cooked food. Not just point and click and there it is at the door in ten minutes. One time I took two minutes to go open the door and a squirrel had already started to tear the pizza box apart.

Fantastic Friday grid. It was a fun solve for my evening. At the LAST SECOND, I noticed Dr P is back today! Glad to see you changed your mind @SP. This forum wouldnâ€™t be the same without you. Thank you to Geoffrey and Rafael for starting off my weekend without any RED FLAGS ðŸš©

Just finished the LA Times crossword (am I allowed to say that here?) and it was co-constructed by Geoffrey Schorkopf. What are the odds of having two puzzles come out on the same day?  I was happy to see his name because I thoroughly enjoyed todayâ€™s NYT puzzle and he did not disappoint.  Check it out!

This was way too hard for me.

The top half of the puzzle simply featured too many things I didn't know: REALID, ITSASMALLWORLD, JICAMA, HERS, [PLOP]ART, and GINSLING. I'm only somewhat aware of the word OENOPHILIA, but given how little crosses I had in that area, and how late-week the clue was, there was no way I would have been able to get it today. The result? I was so lost there I didn't even bother looking stuff up - I resorted to reveals.

I've been a gamer for almost 40 years now and I've defeated thousands of bosses, if not tens of thousands. I've never used, heard or seen the term BOSS BATTLE - for me it's always been a BOSS *fight*. The entry was still a gimme, since "fight" didn't fit and "battle" was the only alternative that made sense (in a way), but I didn't like it one bit.

I don't get why "Entered a bear market, say" solves to SLID. Any help, please? Of course it's not covered by the "tricky" clues section of the column. "A random selection of clues, explained", more like.

Butter BEAN. Ok. But... Wax BEAN? BEAN wax? What's that?

It always feels rotten to fail not because of clever misdirection but simply because the grid is so full of personal unknows. So no, I did not enjoy the solve.

userLocation: no longer writing like E. E. Cummings
commentBody:
I believe Mr. Musa  and Robyn Weintraub must ritually ingest before constructing the same mysterious psychedelic which induces in the user a trance-like state resulting in exquisitely artful and delightful clueing.
One of my favorite setters and a cleansing Friday grid.

"This tiny blender doesn't purÃ©e anything!"
"It's a small whirl after all."

("I have mixed feelings about that.")

userLocation: no longer writing like E. E. Cummings
commentBody:
Oh my.

Today's mini took a little hit off a Thursday maxi's hash pipe.
Tough one for me tonight but I learned a lot. I especially like "lifestyle creep", for its applicability to both one's behavior and certain public figures.
Unique mini puzzle today. Joel has really been rocking it lately. I love the creativity coming out in his puzzles.
wonderful puzzle was sipping some Red during solve no spoilers bravo guys!

this puzzle on reflection is a classic reason being it's not reliant on overused tropes -  its one banger after another and funny! deriving meaning is always way more fun than recycling trivia kudos to editors thank the Universe Bezos doesn't own the Times
It turns out OENEOPHorIA must not be a thing.
This one came together nicely and quickly. So glad I solved this since I bombed on Wordle and  Connections.
A little longer than average, start in bed, wake up at 2 a.m. and start to see the words. A perfect puzzle.
Loved it

Quite chewy, but interesting and lively fill. 
One query; what on earth were you all using at 2D before 2025??

Our brand new Grandson arrived last night. Beyond excited to meet him today, our reign as Grandparents begins. Apparently you can hand them back when they start crying, unlike when youâ€™ve birthed them yourself and are stuck with the little blighters.
That was a hard one for me! Except for Disney, of course.

Nice puzzle packed with some great debuts. I liked TINY HOME crossing LIFESTYLE CREEP. For some truly bad PLOP ART, here's Lucille Ball: https://time.com/4442285/lucille-ball-statue-scary-lucy/ Luckily, after 6 years, it was replaced with a better likeness.

The only time you would hear "OLE" at any football stadium in Brasil is if it were an international match against a Spanish/Hispanic team. No Brazilian says "OLE" at football matches! (The editors presumably know that Portuguese is spoken in Brasil). One might yell many things -- three letter examples could include "GOL", "OBA" or "PQP!" :)

Hope to see all the aminophiles out for the peptide rally.



Nice to see a puzzle with a bit of muscle and gristle to end the work week (for those who work).
Two that I considered were PoOPART and BOSSBAddiE but I got them from the crossings. Lol

This was a buttery, smooth solve
with *just* the right amount of 
brow-squinching for me.

Heading to the airport to trade 
slush, ice, and frostbite
for palm trees,'ocean,
and my other man-kid.

Happy Friday all!
Treat yourself to something extra.
Can someone explain how Mason solves to HARDHAT? I donâ€™t see any reference to that as a name for a mason.
I thought for a moment that [Reds' fandom?] might be COMMUNISTS. It has the right number of letters!

Does anyone think the puzzles have been a little easier lately? I'm on a 22-puzzle streak, which is really good for me, and I haven't been struggling the way I usually do. Sure, maybe I'm getting better, but after all these years...? What do y'all think?

@SamCorbin

While I bristled a little at the hooligan clue, our local pro Soccer team is the Tampa Bay Rowdies, so I guess it makes sense.

LIFESTYLE CREEP â€“ Oh, perfect term!  Gorgeous!  Many TILâ€™s are instantly forgettable.  This one is now etched in and I will think it when I see it.  Mwah!  

Freshness: Nine NYT never-seen-before answers with their never seen before clues, including LIFESTYLE CREEP itself, as well as its antithesis (as Rex Parker brilliantly pointed out today) TINY HOME. 

Skilled cluing:  Look at the one for OENOPHILIA, which in lesser hands would be given a direct clue, but here the clue is a misdirect, sounding baseball related -- Mwah again!  

My sheesh moment was when, with [Word with wax or butter], I fixated on the answer preceding those words, so when BEAN emerged, I actually spent more moments than Iâ€™d like to admit wondering what bean butter and bean wax were.

I liked ICK sharing the grid with PLOP ART, as well as a trio of lovely smaller answers JICAMA, INLAY, and HIT UP.

Lovely, skilled, and fresh â€“ a satisfying jewel of a puzzle.  High props, Geoffrey and Rafael, and a big thank you!

This was a terrific grid with a few (too few) standout clues including [Reds' fandom] and . . . 

Hmm, guess that's it.

Typical tough Friday for me with more than a couple of complete unknowns as clued. Had to google a couple of things and then it was just a lot of working the crosses until finally dawned on me. Ended up being an enjoyable workout. And... ... my usual puzzle find today. A Monday from September 8, 2014 by Dan Schoenholz. Three 'theme' answers in that one, though they were not identified as such and they all had straightforward clues: BOOKOFMORMON DOORTODOOR VOODOODOLL And the 'reveal': "Milestone birthday, informally ... with a hint to 20-, 31-, and 41-across." THEBIGFIVEOH Always nice to find something a bit different. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/8/2014&g=39&d=D ...
I had "LIFESTYLEGREED" for a while...

So many personal resonances in this excellent puzzle! Let's start with Ursula K. LeGuin's *The LATHE of Heaven*. "Eighty dolls yelling 'small girl after all'": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n4WfWZPCnn8&list=RDn4WfWZPCnn8&start_radio=1 (Sorry for the bad lyrics video, but for a hoot, watch the official one with the CC turned on!") "When I look at you, I see a rotund little budget-friendly me": https://www.youtube.com/shorts/ZDwrzOkC6GI [Tiny feature of a spork] gave me a bit of a problem, despite being a backpacker--I would call them "tines." My sporks have tiny clips, presumably so one could clip them to one's tool-belt, but I doubt that's a standard feature. But why has the spork never caught on, outside of the Great Outdoors? Eminently practical, especially when served apple pie, or birthday cake, a la mode. But here's my linguistic discovery of the day: "Spork" was originally a proprietary trademark--this I knew, although I'm not sure who held, or holds the trademark. But "Spork" was already an entry in the 1909 edition of the Century Dictionary, where it was described as "a 'portmanteau-word'". Wait! The term "portmanteau-word" was coined by Lewis Carroll, in *Though the Looking-glass*, which was published in 1871. By 1909, was the term common enough to be used as a descriptor in a dictionary entry? Finally, @Andrzej, I'm now reading Natalie Haynes' book of essays on (monstrous) women in Greek mythology, so a picture of a cute little echidna was happy coincidence!

TIL PLOP ART. I'm a little disappointed in myself that I've never run across that phrase before. As a teacher of Aesthetics, I had a unit on the controversies over public art, focusing on Richard Serra's Tilted Arc and Maya Lin's Vietnam War Memorial. Knowing the word PLOP ART would have made that unit substantially more amusing. https://archiveofdestruction.com/artwork/tilted-arc/ https://art21.org/read/the-black-gash-of-shame-revisiting-the-vietnam-veterans-memorial-controversy/

An echidna blowing snot bubbles from the edge of its snifter?
Nothing to snift at. Love that photo choice, Sam.

Excellent puzzle, Geoffrey and Rafael, thanks.

I dithered a bit at 55D, clam and oyster BarS, and 62A, BEes wax or butter.
"The ambiguity is criminal."
That applies beyond the puzzle these days.
TIL that OENOPHILIA has the same number of letters as CINCINATTI.

As an oenophile, I loved this quick & clever Friday - cheers!

Also, may I suggest another name to add to the clue for 56A that would be more timely - Mikaela Shiffrin â›·ï¸.

"My echidna is missing!"
"I'll issue an all-points bulletin."

("You're quilling me, Smalls")
Really liked this puzzle, felt spot on for a Friday. Thanks, G & R.
Great clues, no groaners, awesome Friday
Can I really be the first to mention â€œOpnam Gangnam Styleâ€?  Sorry â€¦

Note to future constructors: Mr Toad's Wild Ride has 15 letters, a proper weekday spanner. I must have skipped the ride at 22A, but I remember the "Simpsons" parody. "Duff Beer for me, Duff Beer for you, I'll have a Duff Beer, you'll have one too."

I enjoyed the constructorsâ€™ note and the puzz today (although I too was hoping for PoOP ART). LIFESTYLE CREEP was new to me, but I canâ€™t wait to use it, and the clue for 14A was phenomenal. Interesting insight into the problem with 14-letter entries, too. Thanks, constructors & eds!

Enjoyed this one, which felt like a solid Friday puzzle to me. Solved it without help in about 30 minutes, but had to work all the way. Several entries were unfamiliar to me, but all were discernible from the crosses. GPSWATCH seemed a bit contrived, but, OK, it made the puzzle come together.

Hope tomorrow's is even harder!
Thanks for the earworm. Loved the clue for OWL. I live close to the original PoOPART in San Jose. Never heard of PLOPART. https://share.google/sf442gap0HX7RovdT

I started to post this in Jaqui J's space, but rather than decided to use my own space. I like reading her posts.

In the year I've been on this board, more than a few long-timers and prominent posters have taken hiatus. I'm not either of those two categories, but I had to throw in the towel at one point. Regrettably, I opted to resurface during this recent Great Southern Freeze-out. Perhaps going back in to the witness protection program is better suited for me again(?). 

I belong to only one other on-line forum, which is guitar-player oriented, and it's nothing like this one. It's much less contentious and essentially zero politics. I try to keep up my (now diminishing) writing skills through my memoirs and by posting a blog. That, and periodically going through algebra problems. There's always another X to solve.
 
I want for SP, and several other great writers and scholars here, to continue to serve us with their artistic writing skills. I miss being around minds such as theirs since I've been retired. I gain lots of unique insight into what great minds think and I applaud their sharing it.
This was the easiest Friday for me so far. I'm not complaining, I usually struggle through a Thursday and find Sundays harder than Saturdays. I had fun with this one.

This was a solid Friday puzzle.  One thing in particular I liked about this puzzle is that the difficulty level seemed pretty consistent from start to finish, which I imagine may not be the easiest thing for constructors and editors to achieve (but I don't dismiss that part of that can be due to a solver's unique bank of knowledge).

Took 10% less time than average, but I feel lucky that it did not take longer.
Very good puzzle overall, but I bristled at rowdy as a noun as well. That one clue added minutes and frustration to an otherwise lovely solve.

I don't know about y'all, but I've seen a wild kid who was a HOOLIGAN but none I'd call "A rowdy."  One's a noun, the other's an adjective.  Would you rather deal with one HOOLIGAN or an entire class that's rowdy?  Teach at a junior high!  You'll never be bored!

I had POOP ART at 7D....much better than PLOP ART imho.

Rafael mentors another partner in crime, eh?  
AS IF I CARED ...I DON'T CAREugh OH SO SCARED sheesh

Carry your MULTIPURPOSE Swiss Army knife into the airport and you'll get invited into a small room.  Once upon a time, every gentleman had a small pen-knife in his pocket...  

Anyone else here ever use any iteration of ANGIe's List?  Totally worthless.  (Hey, Wendy in Conway, AR:  Handyman 4 Hire is the best!  His card reads, "We show up!"  And he will.)

The clues were tilted just enough to keep me guessing (which I try to avoid), and had me heading off in wrong directions. (Something) greed? Is there a team called the gUBS? 

Looking back, it all seems so confident and solid, very professionally cool, but solving it, well, that was a bit of a challenge. When oenophilia emerged, I did a forehead slap and saw the red. I had been so fixated on a sports team that I felt like some dumb hooligan off the street, with no class at all. 

Dario, it isn't easy to pull off a Thursday with just plain old ordinary, sophisticated cluing, but you did it, and with a debut puzzle. Congratulations.

Am I just getting dumber? When I started doing these puzzles a few years ago, I had lots of difficulty and needed many lookupsâ€” no surprises there, and no shame. But then I got better and for a long time, I was cruising through most puzzles with only an occasional hiccup.

But latelyâ€¦ Iâ€™m seeing lots of â€œeasyâ€ comments about puzzles that were very challenging for me. Today, I got stuck early on and had to turn on â€œcheck puzzleâ€ mode before I was even halfway through. I havenâ€™t done that since the early days. Is it just me? Or are some recent puzzles objectively harder than the norm? Maybe itâ€™s just brain numbing from the barrage of current events, but Iâ€™m starting to think I need to practice drawing some clocks.
The crosses of OENOPHILIA with GPSWATCH and PLOPART broke my 32 day streak. So mad. Nice puzzle though. Still have more mundane things to memorize before I become a crossword master.
Were some of the clues were to a different puzzle? But I suppose that's a very easy way to make it more difficult.

There was a very active thread that covered several topics, and now it is deleted.  Why?

One of the topics was about deletion of comments.  How ironic and frustrating for those participating that it was deleted.  I wish NYT would err on the side of not deleting comments.  If some comment is inappropriate, commenters typically are quick to call it out.  I prefer freedom of expression, as long as one is not personally attacking someone (or something) in a hateful manner.

Perfect Friday puzzle for me. Many, if not most, of the clues took two or three passes to make sense of, and when they did, were a delightful surprise. I enjoyed this one straight through from start to finish.

Held myself up a little bit at the end with W_A_S to finish a season, trying various consonants for the public ART. Which I complicated by thinking "Hearts are___for the breakin'" might refer to a second elided word. (I should read more of her lyrics. I appreciate them more in written form.)

I felt a bit sheepish at how long it took to see WRAPS. But that was kind of how a lot of this puzzle felt, with a "But of course!" popping out time and time again.
I had a much more scatological guess for the first word of 7D.

I feel like I woke up a bit late and the culture changed while I was dozing. 
"plop art?" "lifestyle creep?" "bean butter/ butter bean?" 
I have apparently been living under a rock. 
But in good news, I was able to compose an amusing riddle in my head to which the answer is: "Lifestyle creep." 
The problem is, I can't tell you the prompting question in a family newspaper. You'll have to derive your own from the news.

This was a fair Friday puzzle but I feel it had some rather shoddy clues but I guess thatâ€™s part of a Friday puzzle.

Finished without lookups but 6 minutes longer than usual. That NorthWest corner can eat a D($@
I loved this one! Felt very challenging while doing it, yet still finished under my Friday average somehow! That's a win in my book!

Actually, has anyone else had the following experience? I finish a puzzle like today's, for example, and look at my completion time. Then I look at the completion time listed for "Today" in the "Your Statistics" section, and it's a different time. This has happened to me more than once, and because I wasn't tracking my own time, I am not sure which completion time is correct. Anyone else have this happen?
Please fix the archive bug. I have to go back 10 years to find the puzzles I was working on. It used to hold your place.
Similar to Sam and other solvers, I also got silly on 7D. But mine was PopfART, as in a very made-up term for pop art. Delightful.
Fridays always make me reflect on how bad I am at crosswords. Oh well. Challenging and some clever clues.  Thank you, creator. Cheers.
9:10 for me with no lookups, a new Friday record!
Lots of fun clues today, thank you!
can someone explain the "wait wait panel..." clue. What does it refer to?
NYT published an article on Jan 4th that Tom Brady is not the GOAT - jus sayin.

Gah!

ETTA James! Not ELLA Fitzgerald! I spent hours stuck on that area because of that mistake. 
My thoughts: "Hmm - LEATRO must be an Italian word I'm not familiar with."
"I guess ... a really good SALE would 'quench' my thirst for a good bargain?"

Still new to the crosswords...this was close to a Friday PR for me! My mark of shame though is failing to understand TOTALLIE to the point that I googled it multiple times and couldn't figure out why no one was asking what a "totallie" was. Now, a "total lie"-- that I understand!
Excellent Friday.....Olympics showing once again it's a small world after all.  Time for oenophiles to TG!
I really wanted PARIART to be right. Sigh.

Todayâ€™s poem made from the words in todayâ€™s puzz (across clues; down clues; answers)

a/ is time created in sand
a phenomenon embedded in wax
reach through time
with a tiny digging spork
isnâ€™t time pointless
or is time music
and through music isnâ€™t time digging through the soul
ring ring ring - thatâ€™s time - thatâ€™s the pointless
spork of time played out d/ as a
warning that you sang to a/ in
â€œitâ€™s a small worldâ€
ACTS for "Isn't oneself?" is elegant but would have been even more so without the punctuation hint.

OENOP_____ had me convinced I had mistakes somewhere. Never heard of that word before. Between that and having JPEG instead of JPGS killed me, had to give up and Check Puzzle.

Overall this was closer than I usually get on a Friday, but I didnâ€™t like this one much. Relatively few really clever clues.

39 across. The clue written is â€œoleâ€. MaracanÃ£ is the stadium in Rio. Brazilian Portuguese is spoken. 
Ole is a cheer for Spanish speakers. More specifically is used in Spain at the football games. 
Just clarifying. Thank you

It's only a few hours before the next puzzle is released, but I've seen so many comments complaining about, and arguing against, "rowdy as a noun", that I have to step in. Of course our esteemed columnist made a complaint as well, and I tried to be quiet, but I'm just getting a bit too annoyed at the lack of knowledge being exhibited - especially by a professional wordsmith being paid to write about words and word games - to not chastise those who are less well read than they should be. Of course rowdy is a noun. Has been for close to 200 years (Merriam-Webster says the first know use as a noun was in 1832). Don't think so? Even the quintessential American man of letters, Mark Twain, used "rowdy" as a noun: "The blackbird is a perfect gentleman, in deportment and attire, and is not noisy, I believe, except when holding religious services and political conventions in a tree; but this Indian sham Quaker is just a ROWDY [emphasis added], and is always noisy when awake--always chaffing, scolding, scoffing, laughing, ripping, and cursing, and carrying on about something or other". https://www.twainquotes.com/Crow.html

Classic case of a puzzle having some seemingly easy initial fills that turned out to be about three levels of correctness below the actual answers. 

AILS instead of ACTS, MOB instead of APB, OTIS instead of ETTA, REDS instead of CUBS, SOLD instead of SLID, SHEA instead of BEAN, and so on.

Only way I can solve a puzzle like this is to be willing to get rid of any fill on the spot, no matter how badly I wanted it to be right.

ohhhh those clues!!

misdirected on several, so fun to finish

i love it when i see a puzzle and i think it's gonna be so hard, and then i get it

happy friday, everyone!
I was seeing red endeavoring to find the right word.
I feel like LIFESTYLECREEP could also be used to describe most social media influencers.
This was possibly the most enjoyable crossword puzzle I've ever had the pleasure to solve. Kudos to the creators.

My first Friday ever. And well under an hour. Getting the iconic Disney ride corrected all my errors and misdirects.

I might be getting better at this. Let's see how Saturday goes.

Indeed, a good crossword with fellow cruciverbalists is a great way to relax into the weekend.

Coincidentally, earlier this evening, I heard Moira Rose use OENOPHILIA in Schitt's Creek wrt Herb Ertlinger and his Fruit Wines. As a balm after the very sad news last week, I've been rewatching the show and other gems with the incomparable Catherine O'Hara. What a light...

PLOP ART is a new and amusing term for me. As is echidna, particularly ones blowing bubbles :)
Can someone explain the significance of the echidna photograph? I seem to be the only person who doesn't get it, but I'd like to be in on the joke.

An errant p at the end of SLIp was nearly my undoing. Iâ€™m pretty sure it was a typo on 23D when I was really tired last night because the tense didnâ€™t match, but it took me a long time to revisit that area in the first place. I just figured a HARpHAT was some elaborate style I hadnâ€™t heard of yetâ€¦
Why the question mark on 5D?  GPSWATCH answered the clue without any pun or wordplay that I could see.
@Thad its 10:18. I'm done at 16 mins, I think that is a record too!

@Allison

Did you read the column?

@Allison

It would fit in well with poopular culture.
@Steve L nope, but I'm glad I'm not alone!
@Allison Same! It seemed perfect.
@Allison Poop art is what you get at the rear end of craftsmanship
@Dave K  Iâ€™m right behind you at 1791!

@Nick
Bravo, boys! Looking forward for more reports on this heated rivalry.

@Dave K.

It made me cringe - not the name, but being reminded of the issue. My wife and I live in relative comfort, not struggling financially, at all. We don't give a flying frack about conspicuous luxury - actually I'd never buy an item with a prominently exposed brand name. Now, I teach at university. Most of the students don't have it easy, especially the ones from outside Warsaw - it's Poland's most expensive city, so rents etc. are very high. I see my students save on many things, including food. The cheap, ultra-processed stuff they eat is horrifying. And yet they apparently feel forced to dress head to toe in conspicuously branded clothes. I just hope it's all knock-offs...

@Francis

Flaunting wealth makes me laugh. It's so cheap! Quite the paradox, eh?

Looking at me on the street or at work you'd never guess just how well off my wife and I are. And then there are people who take out a loan to get a luxury car they can't afford, often only to have it repo'ed within months.

I once spoke to a lady who leased an Audi Q7 but was terribly angry when it broke down after the warranty period - because she couldn't afford the repair. She was angry at Audi, not herself... And she could have got a Fiat ðŸ¤·ðŸ½â€â™‚ï¸

commentBody: @Andrzej A bear market on the stock exchange refers to a state of affairs wherein a majority of investors are selling, thereby causing stock prices to drop. This price drop is referred to as a "slide." Wax beans (the name comes from the texture) are among the nightmare foods of my childhood. They often came parboiled and in cans and at school and are the gustatory equivalent of nails on a chalkboard. Never had them fresh. Maybe they're better? Here's a nausea-inducing (for me) recipe: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OT2-kTsla6I

@Andrzej

Can't help with the rest, but the Bear Market in US lingo is when stock prices fall because of general lack of enthusiasm among buyers.  A bear market is one in which prices are SLIDing downward.

The opposite is a Bull Market.

Personally, I think the whole system is Bee Ess, where the B can stand for either bear or bull.

Ok, apparently I'm familiar with wax bean, but under its Polish name of "fasolka szparagowa" (literally "asparagus little beans"). It's one of the staples of Polish cooking, and a favorite with peopleof all ages, including kids. It never comes from a can over here - we buy it fresh, cook in salted (and possibly slightly sugary) water, and serve with "zasmaÅ¼ka" - fine bread crumbs fried in butter. It's an absolutely delicious side dish.

I'm hopeless with stock exchange terminology. I can never remember if a bear market is good or bad (it sounds like it might be good - big and strong, no?), and I've never heard of "slide" in this context, or at least I don't remember having heard it.

@Andrzej
Wax BEANS are similar to green string beans but theyâ€™re yellow. I was curious about SLID too.  I think â€œEntering a bear marketâ€ refers to a decline in the stock market so SLID refers to a downward trend? I only got it on the crosses.  Sorry you didnâ€™t enjoy the puzzle!  It wasnâ€™t that easy, but I lucked out with knowing  a lot of the answers without lookups.

@Heidi

Thanks ðŸ˜ƒ

@Valerie I started 23D with SolD which disappeared at the next crossing. Referring to the opposing market factions by these names began with a Victorian-era stock market game. Here is an example of non-PLOP ART: https://www.gettyimages.co.uk/photos/wall-street-statue-bull I join Matt in his repulsion at the wax bean which is unsalvageable by any method of preparation known to human kind. Notwithstanding Andrzej's blandishments, wax beans are useful only for composting.

@Andrzej

I think BOSS BATTLE might be more common in reference to JRPGs where you traditionally control multiple party members; â€œfightâ€ would sound wrong to me if youâ€™re talking about Final Fantasy VII or Chrono Trigger, but it would sound more apt to me if youâ€™re playing, say, one of the Resident Evil games.

@Nick

I was in a semi-hardcore World of Warcraft raiding guild in the late 2000s. We never called our boss fights battles, and neither did the game guides.

commentBody:
@Matt

Glad you asked!

World of Warcraft is a Massively Multiplayer Online (MMO) game, where the most challenging content must be done by a group of players. "Raids" are the toughest places featuring bosses, so called because you need a whole bunch of people to defeat them - a raid group. Originally raids in WoW were designed for 40 people, which later changed to 10 and 25 variants. Raids in WoW come in several difficulties. Hardcore raiding guilds do the toughest difficulties. And that was how I got my kicks for a year or so in my late 20s. It was great fun but ultimately I grew tired of facing constant challenges and I morphed into a casual player. The character I played then - the unstoppable female Draenei Death Knight DeathOfRats - still exists, hibernating on my inactive WoW account.

Thanks for your attention.

@Andrzej
My experience is just the same plus not knowing PSY or ANGI.
The 'iconic' ITS A SMALL WORLD doesn't sound very exciting so I looked it up - hundreds of singing dolls 'frolicking in a spirit of international unity'. 
I have no words.

@Jane Wheelaghan

It's the kind of ride that in the 1990s grandmothers of the time loved to take their grandkids on, thinking it was all so sweet and cute.  I've been on it with parent and child several times.

It was ok.  I didn't hate it.

But the grandkids and I preferred the Pirates of the Caribbean.
@Andrzej DeathofRats? Sounds like a Terry Pratchett reference!

@J

T'was.

My wife also played. Her Death Knight was a gnome called GrimSqueaker. Sheer brilliance.

When the Death Knight (DK) class was released in WoW in 2008 with the Wrath of the Lich King expansion (it was the heyday of that game), the game world was flooded with DK characters with such cringey names as DeathLord, DeathKing, LordOfDeath etc. (I always imagined pimply teenage boys must have been behind those). I loved how my DeathOfRats made fun of it all ðŸ˜†
@Francis Or the Space Mountain! That was the first one that came to mind, but it was one letter short. :-)

@Andrzej I agree that the classification of bull = rising market, bear = sliding market is completely arbitrary.

I _think_ what it is trying to convey is the image of a bear hibernating as the analogy of a "boring" market, and the bull as a symbol of macho aggression, which stereotypical wall street traders identify with. But they might have as well have gone with the bear for the same thing, like the berserkers of old...

@Matt
OMG, and I thought I was the only one who had to endure the childhood horror of wax beans! Unlike my grandmother, my mother was not a good cook, and wax beans were a horrible example. They were also served at room temperature straight out of the can, sometimes along with beef liver broiled until it had the consistency of shoe leather because, you know, kosher. First thing I did when I left home was to learn how to cook real food.

@Times Rita

A violation of the 8th amendment.

@Times Rita
I love wax beans, Lima beans, kale and spinach. Hate tomatoes.

@Andrzej

If it helps, a bull attacks you and lifts you UP with your horns and throws you. A bear smashes you DOWN with its paws. At least thatâ€™s the image I envision.

@Matt - Andrezj, the 8th Amendment to the US Constitution forbids the cruel and unusual punishment of eating American-style wax beans.  If only our mothers were constitutional scholars  we would have been spared.  They do show up in three bean salad,   which some people like.

@jennie

What *do* you people do to those beans that they're such a horror? Is it the canning? Ours really are good, and I'm quite a picky eater.

@Andrzej

They have all flavor painstakingly removed through a combination of hours of washboarding and being repeatedly flung against rocks in extremely hot climates where they are thereupon left to dessicate for days.  They are then injected with extra wax and reconstituted with hypersalinated bog water.

@Jane Wheelaghan The original ITS A SMALL WORLD was installed at the 1964-65 New York Worldâ€™s Fair and then transported to Disneyland. Replicas have since been built at other Disney parks. The main reason itâ€™s ironically iconic is the music, which many consider the most insidious ear worm of all time.

@Jeff Z

What do I think?

I think you just threw a book of burning matches into a stuffed fireworks warehouse.

I hope I'm taping into sort of a forum joke about past discussions on the topic.

@Jeff Z

They are undeniably much, much easier than they were in the past, this week especially so. Unfortunately, the easier they are, the more attractive they seem to be to the subscriber base, so I doubt weâ€™re ever going back. The Games section basically subsidizes the rest of the paper at this point.

@Jeff Z They've been getting easier for years, there is zero doubt. I've been working through the archives; today would be a Wednesday 10 years ago. 

I still solve daily, but the weekends are often letdowns because of their ease.

@Jeff Z  They've definitely been easier for the past several weeks (months?). My solve times for the harder days are generally half of what they used to be. (Today's puzzle not so much, but still not too challenging for a Friday. Had a few mistakes that were slowing me down.) I think the proliferation of commonplace phrases as answers, like 17- and 60-Across, is one of the causes.

@Jeff Z Yes,  thank you for speaking truth to power.I have been disappointed this last year at the dumbing down, which the puzzle editors have defended as necessary to attract paying solvers.  Friday and Saturday still hold challenges but the rest of the week is generally rather dull for me. But admittedly I have many decades of experience. The New Yorker is refreshing, but even that is not really difficult. I would love it if someone would point me to the best challenges available.

@Jeff Z I feel like this is generally the caseâ€”puzzles are getting easierâ€”but i donâ€™t think thatâ€™s the whole story. Occasionally, very challenging puzzles do still crop up, and not just on Saturdays. I say that not to nitpick, but to suggest that the editors are at least *trying* to keep something here for everyone, despite the commercial pressures others in this thread have observed.
@Joe - The Games in my local paper are very important to our subscription!

@Joe

Back before the separate Games subscription existed, the subscriber base was those who subscribed to, and read, the newspaper in general.  

Back in 1997 (I think it was), they took their first step toward widening the subscriber base, by being one of the last newspapers to print in full color.   Other steps came later, including more mass market sections and features.

The spinning off of the Games as its own subscription was one of the most recent steps.  After all, who wouldn't want a word game that practically everyone can solve, and which takes one or two minutes (Wordle) or one that usually takes three or four (Connections).  

And who needs thoughtful puzzles like the second Sunday variety puzzles, like the Acrostic and Puns & Anagrams, which now appear print-only (for those who actually read the whole paper) or on xwordinfo.com (for hardcore fans).

At least, there are still no comics.

@Dawn
But try it in the singular (as HOOLIGAN is) and it's really....No.

@John Carson

Sweet put down, respect!

@John Carson, somebody posited the other day that the puzzles in the last two weeks, which seem decidedly easier, could be catering to the wider audience the NYT is seeking with the barrage of ads to share oneâ€™s subscription with family members. 

I think thatâ€™s an interesting theory, because thereâ€™s no question that the late-week puzzles have been easier than usual recently. I hope we go back to the more typical meaty challenges soon. While itâ€™s exciting to have personal-record-breaking solve times, I prefer the satisfaction from finishing a difficult puzzle.

@CQ
Were you talking about the 2002 version of *Lathe*, or the 1980 made-for-(PBS)-television one? The latter stars Bruce Davidson and Margaret Avery, so the acting is quite good. Yes, the special effects, etc., are laughably bad by current standards, but, hey, it's (early) PBS, and didn't we all wear and do things in 1980 that would embarrass us today? I know I did. And some of the scenes--the dinner-party dream sequence, for example--are quite effective.

In my, and many others', opinions, it is _the_only_ decent adaptation of a UKL work (she was closely involved in the production.)

And, it's available for viewing, in its entirety, on, um YouTube.

@ NJ: Well, I think you're cute!

@Bill
I understand the spork to be a modern coinage, but not a modern invention. I remember my grandmotherâ€™s silver had small spoons with tines at the edge. We used them for pie ala mode. I was taught that they were called runcible spoons, a word I believe was made up by Edward Lear, used in his poem â€œThe Owl and the Pussycat,â€ a childhood favorite of mine. This was in the early 1960s.

@The X-Phile

I'm a Vietnam veteran. Was in a company known as 'hard-luck Alpha.' There are about 35 names on that wall from my company during my time there. And.. I'm still in touch online with many members of that company, including our commanding officer who eventually became a general.

As to the attitudes about the wall... I don't care. Those who were there know what it was like, and the misconceptions spread by those who opposed the war are... whatever. Doesn't matter. There's us and there's everybody else and that's it. 

....

@Rich in Atlanta

Wow.

Respect. ðŸ‘ðŸ«¡

Wow.

@The X-Phile
I didn't realize that the VietNam War Memorial had been so controversial.  When I stood there, its power was overwhelming.  
I found my classmate's name, thinking of his sister Pam and his mother (a nurse when I had surgery)...  Stevie was only 19.  
I don't know how anyone can stand there without weeping.

@Mean Old Lady

As someone who narrowly escaped being a nominee for that wall, I approach it with the deepest of respect.

I didn't run, though I wanted to.  I didn't take deferments, though I wanted to.  

But, in the end, I was not called.

Still, the thought that your name could replace one there...it's hard to describe that sort of feeling.

But it's probably a feeling that everyone should have at some point in their lives, that feeling of "there but for the grace of God, go I".

And that feeling is appropriate for so much of life.

@The X-Phile
I remember when they put up the "bubblegum" statue of Albert Einstein, plopped down on a bench in DC. (Robert Berks.) It was not well-received at the time, but the tourists love to have their picture taken sitting in his lap. Anything by Richard Serra is terrible, or maybe I'm missing something?

Rich,
Don't mean nothin'.

@Grant

Some people don't much like abstract art, and some people don't like (post-)minimalism, and everyone is entitled to their preferences.
But I've found that there's much more to Serra's work than appears at first glance, and I think his work needs to be experienced first hand in order to be appreciated.

But with public art, whose opinion should be considered?  How do we respect all views?

@The X-Phile

Yes, that one was new to meas well. But the crosses were kind enough.

@Rich in Atlanta I found the Vietnam War Memorial very moving when I saw it.  Seeing notes there, flowers placed there, veterans touching it, people holding up children to read names, made it a moving experience.  I may have been opposed to the war but not the people who had to go.  As a country, we treated you badly when you returned.

@Rich in Atlanta

I respect your opinion and agree with it. But, as I'm sure you know, most of those who opposed the Memorial were not those who opposed the War, but veterans who thought the Memorial disrespected their service, calling it a "black gash of shame."

@Francis
The year my name would have been in the lottery had I not been female, my birthday was #1. I thought it was kind of funny until I realized my brother would be in the lottery the next year. 

I, too, cried at the wall. I had a classmate on there, but it was the sheer enormity of it, that overpowering sense of "but for the grace of God." I was in relationship with a veteran who was unable even to look at it.

I, too, was against the war, partly for the effect I saw it having on several other friends who had returned. I didn't know what the solution to what was going on over there was, but was pretty sure what we were doing was not it.

@Rich in Atlanta,

Well said, Rich.

@Mean Old Lady
I had the same reaction the first time I saw it and found several high school classmate names. A deeply moving experience.

@Francis
With all due respect, are you saying you didn't serve yet you narrowly escaped being on the wall?

@Rich in Atlanta
 i love that piece ~ and there are many more public art pieces that inspire me ~ thank you for your service!

@Mean Old Lady I'll post this info as a separate comment, but the quintessential American man of letters, Mark Twain, used "rowdy" as a noun, so it must be so. https://www.twainquotes.com/Crow.html The quote: "The blackbird is a perfect gentleman, in deportment and attire, and is not noisy, I believe, except when holding religious services and political conventions in a tree; but this Indian sham Quaker is just a rowdy, and is always noisy when awake--always chaffing, scolding, scoffing, laughing, ripping, and cursing, and carrying on about something or other".

Web page code uses angle brackets to separate code from content. One way of hacking a website was to inject malicious code into the site via comments etc, so well run sites will strip out anything with angles brackets.

I used to keep track of my streak, and it was probably about a year of so after doing the puzzles daily that my streak was roughly about what yours was before today.  It wasn't much later that i decided to stop being a slave to the streak, and have enjoyed the puzzle more since.

Don't get me wrong -- as a sometimes competitive person, and can see how keeping track of the streak can be enjoyable, but for me it started to detract from the pleasure.  The real pleasure I get is just from sticking with a hard puzzle until it is completed without outside help.
